data.title: Filter Make GPU Memory Leak

data.body:
@morvans and @carlosrovira

you guys were the only one who edited pom.xml, and now build is broken.
Have you even tested it before submitting changes?
https://github.com/PrimaryFeather/Starling-Framework/commits/master/starling/build/maven/pom.xml

Here are some explanations:

The change https://github.com/PrimaryFeather/Starling-Framework/commit/7f3742de599c59b59f3484f3455213cbba7c116b by @carlosrovira is 100% build-break — there are no dependencies available with artifact id "org.apache.flex" and version 4.9.1.1447119. Why would you set and commit this without even trying to build?

@morvans not sure about your commits. Are you sure there is playerglobal version 11.4 available at public repository? And why did you change flex sdk version?

Daniel, you'd better filter pull requests ;)

data.title: Creating TextField or FragmentFilter while context is lost causes crash
data.body: This is because TextField doesn't check if context is present and tries to upload texture on disposed context. If I use bitmap fonts app suffers another issue: QuadBatch tries to create new vertexbuffer on disposed context in order to increase its capacity.

data.title: AssetManager: purgeQueue can produce texture leak
data.body:
Hi!

Using url string as asset in my app, i have found a leak (in rare cases) when you purge the queue and then you enqueue and load new textures (in my case, sounds or another thing could have same problem) in the same frame. 

The problem is in loadRawAsset method and the urlLoader variable. If you purge the queue in the middle of the process, it isn't cancelled. If you load again, you will receive twice onProgress call with different progress (it crashes my app because the progress could be 1.0 without the valid texture loaded) . Also, it added the invalid texture (or sound) that you think that it wasn't loaded, so you can't dispose it.

data.title: Pooling DelayedCalls in Juggler.as
data.body: It would be convenient to have the delayCall method in the Juggler.as class to use a DelayedCall taken from an object pool (the same way it happens with the tween convenience method in Juggler.as). This way when using multiple delayCalls Starling won't have to create and dispose multiple instances of them but could re-use the same one.

data.title: Minor feature request: Enhance stage.drawToBitmapData()
data.body:
While the current stage.drawToBitmapData works perfectly fine, some users want to take advantage of this functionality but optionally render into or create a transparent bitmapData with only the display object hierarchy (sans the backgroundColor).

See:
http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/context3ddrawtobitmapdata-on-ios
and
http://forum.starling-framework.org/topic/render-textures-cant-be-restored-when-the-starlings-render-context-is-lost

Instead of suggesting to people to replicate and copy/paste the code of stage.drawToBitmapData just to call support.clear() it might be useful to extend the existing stage.drawToBitmapData() with something like an additional optional argument like transparent:Boolean = false to optionally draw just with clear() instead of using backgroundColor if true (as well as creating the new instance BitmapData (if the one supplied is null) with transparent property as well in its constructor).

Just a thought.

data.title: an AssetManager url parsing bug
Starling: RenderTexture: Flash 11.8 Framerate Slowing Bug
data.body:
Just as a note this bug has been found for the Samsung Galaxy Tab 2 7" and is only visible with the FlashpPlayer 11.8 in a very specific circumstance now i do not know if it's visible in 11.9 b/c i do not have that set up but i will try to test it when i get a chance, all the previous versions are fine from what i can tell though.

caused by the RenderTexture drawBundled function on further investigation i found it was this one line that caused it:

mSupport.clear();

Drops the framerate from 30 -> 6. Huge problem lets just hope this is a specific case and newer versions don't reproduce this bug.

data.title: Sprite(DisplayObjectContainer) should provide clear() to fast remove all children without firing any event.
RenderTexture: Memory Leak
TextField cannot rende unicode text with numbers in it
data.body:
Hello,
I'm seeing a strange issue with textfields using embedded fonts.
I'm trying to render the following text in Japanese: レベル.
This shows up well when using an embedded font like this:

``` as3
[Embed(source = "../assets/fonts/impact.ttf", advancedAntiAliasing="true",fontName = "Impact", fontFamily="Impact", embedAsCFF="false", mimeType = "application/x-font-truetype")]
private static const Impact:Class;

var LevelNameTF:TextField = new TextField(120, 20, "レベル", "Impact", 18, 0xffffff);
```

However, when I try to render the same text with a number in it (レベル 9) only the number shows up and the japanese characters are removed. When I trace out the string I see unicode characters, but they does not show up in the text field. this happens for various unicode characters and font combinations (I've tried Arial as well). When I render just the number everything works fine as well.

Can someone take a few seconds to reproduce this? Is this a known issue?

Thanks!  :)

data.title: mTextBounds null exception on lost context after a TextField font set from ttf to bmp
Starling.onTouch should check if event.isDefaultPrevented()
data.body: Starling.onTouch should check if event.isDefaultPrevented().

data.title: Variable sized image sequence in MovieClip?
data.body:
Hello.

As we all know, memory is precious, especially GPU memory.As I am trying to develop MovieClips using Starling, through SpriteSheets/TextureAtlases, I seem to run into a problem with tightening up my Atlases.

When I play a MovieClip, it seems to get very angry if the texture atlas does not contain a sequence of subimages of the same size. Please Note, it is quite possible that I am doing something else wrong, not using the TextureAtlases and the MovieClip class correctly.

First off, initially, the content of my MovieClips gets stretched if the Image (N+1) in the sequence is of a different size (lets say half of the width) than Image (N). 

I worked around that by subclassing the MovieClip class and overriding the "set texture" function, allowing me to call the Image class function "readjustSize" if the new texture is of a different size than the old texture.

It would be nice to hear Daniels opinion on this. 

With this in place, I managed to get an animation of a rotating object (Wide in some frames, thin in some frames) to play without stretching while ensuring that the Texture Atlas does not have to have a lot of empty alpha pixels between the symbols (to make the individual subtextures are of equal width).

This saves me a lot of pixel space in the TextureAtlas, but maybe this is solved differently/better in other ways?

Does this make sense? Unfortunately, I am unable to provide the sprite sheets I'm using as they are for a upcoming game, but if my words aren't enough to explain what I mean, I'll try to provide something that helps to get this description across.

Thanks for reading! :)

EDIT: OR, alternatively, this might just be a case of me not fully understanding the frameWidth and frameHeight values of the TextureAtlas XML... Hmm...

data.title: Duplicated "for each" statement found in AssetManager.as
Filters - Caching ByteArrays from AGALMiniAssembler?
data.body:
Does anyone else have a problem with Filters being expensive to instantiate?

Or is it just me? :)

One issue we have been running in to is a bit of a performance hit when creating Filters, especially the BlurFilter class.Since I read that we shouldnt use the same Filter for multiple objects, we create a bunch of them. 

However, the assemble method of the AGALMiniAssembler takes a bit of time, and when we are creating multiple instances of the BlurFilter, assemble() gets called multiple times with the same program-string. I have gone through the code and I cant see any difference in the output, ie the same input yields the same output.

This makes me want to cache the generated ByteArray in a Dictionary, store it with a unique identifier (maybe even the program string itself) and check for a cached version of the generated ByteArray and clone that one, instead of re-parsing the same program string in AGALMiniAssembler again and again.

When I implemented this outside of Starling, through a variant of the BlurFilter class, the cost of creating the BlurFilters shrank dramatically.

Is this a problem that others face?

Of course, if applied at the correct level, it could be applied to all areas where programs are generated. For example, the code in QuadBatch.registerPrograms runs about twice as fast with the caching in place. It's a cheap method, sure, but it shows that the performance boost can be had across the board.

Is this something worth digging deeper into? I wouldn't mind putting together a test case for comparison, if anyone would be interested, or I can come with some suggestions on how/where to implement it. BUt before I do anything, I'd like to hear if anyone thinks this is worth doing?

Thanks for a great Framework!

data.title: Remove power of 2 check from useRectTexture
data.body:
I think it makes sense that even if the Texture is a power of 2 (as long as mipmaps is false) that a RectangleTexture is used for the memory saving benefits it offers.

I cannot see any disadvantages to doing this as to use a RectangleTexture mipmaps has to be false

data.title: fixed Image.getBounds and Quad.getBounds for non-zero upper left vertex case.
data.body:
Texture's frame could be used to align images that is a rasterized
version of a flash symbol that have a custom pivot (in the center of an
image for example). In order to get correct bounds (and therefore
hitTest) one has to consider upper left vertex of an Image (Quad).

data.title: Opening up Starling class for overrides?
data.body:
We are working with a mixed Stage and Starling application in Browser-space.

Starling works great, but as we start mixing Stage MouseEvents (which we need due to lots of legacy Stage material) with Starling TouchEvents, we realize that the easiest for
us would be to run Stage MouseEvents with a hook for various starling objects (Only a minority of our GUI elements are Starling objects)

My idea was then to completely disable the Starling onTouch-functionality, since it is pure overhead for us. Sub-Classing the Starling class, overriding what's appropriate and enjoy Starling with the Touch functionality removed.

However, the Starling class hides all the methods that I need to disable onTouch.

Starling onTouch is private
Starling touchEventTypes is private

Is there a specific reason why so many member variables and methods are private rather than protected?

If not, could I come with suggestions for which methods could be made protected? 

Thanks for a fantastic Framework, by the way. I thoroughly love it

data.title: Optimised index calculation
data.body: I have taken out the calculation (multiplication and addition) of the index of mRawData out of the loop and instead index directly into mRawData

data.title: Texture.fromBitmapData scales incorrectly
data.body:
Scenario:
1. There's a bitmapdata with width of 640 px.
2. Texture scaled up to 800px width (scaleFactor 1.25) is needed.
3. Texture is created by calling Texture.fromBitmapData(bmd, false, false, 1.25);

Result: returned texture has a width of 512 px (0.8 of original bitmapdata width)
Expected results: texture width should be 800px (1.25 of original bitmapdata width).

In the Texture.fromBitmapData function resulted texture width should be
data.width \* scale instead of data.width / scale
and height should be
data.height \* scale instead of data.height / scale.

Workaround is to use scale of 1/1.25 = 0.8 that result texture with desired width.
Texture.fromBitmapData(bmd, false, false, 1/scale);

Is this a desired behavior or a bug?

data.title: Add batchable property in Button text
data.body: Since 1.4 added batchable property in TextField. But there is no way to set the property of text within the Button class. Suggest to add a batchable property in Button.

data.title: AssetManager: loadQueue throw error if you purge the queue
data.body:
Hi :)

I have detected a problem that rarely happens, but it breaks my application.

If i load a queue, resume method executes a setTimeout. After that, if i purge the queue, processNext could be called. Then assetInfo throw an error when app gets assetInfo.name because it is null.

My application is very intensive with AssetManager, adding and removing assets. It is a book, and the pages are big textures. The user could move the pages fast, going to cancel the pages will not be visible.

Possible solutions: 
*mAbortLoading will be checked here, but it could be a problem in my application too. 
*You can store timeoutID, and clearTimeout in purgeQueue method.

Kind Regards
